formalpara.title: Figure 5. Targeted gene deletions using transposons.
formalpara.para: To generate a targeted gene deletion, a transposase and a rescuing transgene containing a selection marker (in this case, unc-119) is injected into an unc-119 mutant animal carrying a transposon insertion near or in a gene of interest. Typically, strains carrying a single Mos1 insertion near a gene of interest are obtained from the NemaGENETAG Consortium (Bazopoulou and Tavernarakis 2009; Vallin et al., 2012). Homology-directed repair after a double-strand break (DSB) occurs off the introduced transgene at low frequencies. unc-119(+) is inserted into the genome, and in the case of MosDEL, some portion of the gene is deleted, typically the 5’ region of the gene. In MosTIC, the transgene contains a small insertion, deletion, or point mutation, which is incorporated into the genomic DNA.
